title: Post-Stroke Management
icd10: Z86.73 (Personal history of transient ischemic attack and cerebral infarction without residual deficits)
scope: ** Comprehensive post-stroke care from hospital discharge through long-term outpatient management. Covers secondary stroke prevention (antiplatelet, anticoagulation, statin, BP management), post-stroke rehabilitation, management of post-stroke complications (spasticity, depression, central pain, fatigue, cognitive decline, seizures, pseudobulbar affect), medication optimization, functional recovery monitoring, and return to activities. Excludes acute stroke management (see Acute Ischemic Stroke, ICH templates), acute rehabilitation admission protocols, and TIA workup (see TIA template).

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Baseline for statin optimization; LDL target <70 for secondary prevention; reassess after statin initiation; triglycerides and HDL
Essential/Core Labs.target: LDL <70 mg/dL (SPARCL/TST trials); TC <200; TG <150; HDL >40 (M) / >50 (F)

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Diabetes is major modifiable risk factor; screen all stroke patients; pre-diabetes identification
Essential/Core Labs.target: <7% for most; <6.5% if newly diagnosed; >6.5% → diabetes management

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Anemia (worsens ischemia); polycythemia (thrombotic risk); baseline for anticoagulation; infection screening
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; Hgb >10; plt >100K for anticoagulation; >50K for antiplatelet

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Renal function (medication dosing); electrolytes; hepatic function (statin monitoring); glucose
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; creatinine for DOAC dosing; LFTs for statin safety

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Atrial fibrillation workup; thyroid disease as vascular risk factor; hypothyroidism contributes to hyperlipidemia
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; hyperthyroidism → AF; hypothyroidism → lipid control

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Diabetes screening; acute hyperglycemia management; target glucose 140-180 inpatient
If on warfarin; baseline coagulation; hemorrhagic conversion monitoring
Essential/Core Labs.target: INR 2-3 for AF (unless mechanical valve: 2.5-3.5); stable monthly

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Renal function; microalbuminuria is independent cardiovascular risk marker; hypertensive nephropathy
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; microalbuminuria → aggressive BP and metabolic control

Extended Workup (Second-line).target: <50 nmol/L; elevated → maximize statin + consider PCSK9i; Lp(a)-specific therapies in development

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Better predictor of residual cardiovascular risk than LDL alone; target for patients on statins with LDL at goal
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: <70 mg/dL (or <50 in very high risk); elevated → intensify lipid therapy

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Hyperhomocysteinemia as vascular risk factor; B12/folate deficiency; treat with B vitamins
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: <15 μmol/L; elevated → B12, folate, B6 supplementation

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Quantify proteinuria; chronic kidney disease staging; cardiovascular risk stratification
Heart failure screening; AF-associated cardiomyopathy; elevated in cardioembolic stroke
Deficiency associated with worse stroke outcomes and depression; common in post-stroke patients with limited mobility
If TSH abnormal; thyroid function affects AF and cardiovascular risk

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.target: Normal; positive → hematology referral; may change anticoagulation strategy

Hyperhomocysteinemia evaluation; limited clinical utility for treatment decisions (treat homocysteine regardless)
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.target: Common variants (C677T, A1298C); treatment same regardless

Essential/First-line.timing: Follow-up MRI at 3-6 months post-stroke to assess infarct evolution, hemorrhagic transformation, and new lesions; baseline for comparison
Essential/First-line.target: Infarct maturation; no new lesions; hemorrhagic transformation assessment; chronic changes

Essential/First-line.timing: All ischemic stroke patients need carotid evaluation; re-evaluate annually if stenosis present; post-CEA/CAS surveillance
Essential/First-line.target: <50% stenosis (medical management); 50-69% (consider CEA if symptomatic); ≥70% (CEA/CAS recommended if symptomatic)

Essential/First-line.timing: Cardioembolic source evaluation; LV function; valvular disease; atrial septal abnormalities; intracardiac thrombus
Essential/First-line.target: Normal; LV thrombus → anticoagulation; reduced EF → anticoagulation if <30%; valvular disease → cardiology

Essential/First-line.timing: AF detection; QTc monitoring; MI screening; baseline before antiarrhythmics
Essential/First-line.target: Normal sinus rhythm; AF → anticoagulation; other arrhythmia → cardiology

Essential/First-line.timing: Paroxysmal AF detection; 24-48h capture; initial cardiac rhythm monitoring post-stroke
Essential/First-line.target: Normal sinus rhythm; paroxysmal AF → anticoagulation; other arrhythmia

Extended.timing: If 24-48h Holter negative and cryptogenic stroke; 30-day monitor detects ~12% additional AF; CRYSTAL-AF data
Extended.target: AF detection (even brief episodes ≥30 sec warrant anticoagulation consideration)

Extended.timing: Cryptogenic stroke with negative 30-day monitor; long-term AF detection (up to 3 years); CRYSTAL-AF showed 30% AF detection at 3 years
Extended.target: AF detection; any atrial arrhythmia → anticoagulation decision

Extended.timing: PFO evaluation (present in 25% of population, ~50% of cryptogenic stroke <60 years); left atrial appendage thrombus; aortic arch atheroma
Extended.target: PFO with right-to-left shunt → closure consideration if age <60 and cryptogenic; LAA thrombus → anticoagulation; aortic atheroma → antiplatelet/statin

Extended.timing: Intracranial stenosis evaluation; vertebral artery assessment; follow-up vascular imaging at 3-6 months post-stroke
Extended.target: Stable or improved stenosis; new stenosis → medication optimization; hemodynamically significant → interventional consideration

Extended.timing: If symptomatic intracranial stenosis; assess hemodynamic significance; guide intervention
Extended.target: Normal perfusion despite stenosis (compensated) vs decreased perfusion (symptomatic)

Rare/Specialized.timing: Age <60 with cryptogenic stroke and PFO on TEE with moderate-to-large shunt or atrial septal aneurysm; CLOSE/REDUCE/RESPECT trials
Rare/Specialized.target: PFO anatomy suitable for closure; shunt size; atrial septal aneurysm

Rare/Specialized.timing: Intracranial stenosis characterization; vasculitis evaluation; pre-intervention planning; when non-invasive imaging inconclusive
Rare/Specialized.target: Degree and length of stenosis; collateral circulation; dissection flap; vasculitis pattern

Secondary Prevention (Antiplatelet/Antic.indication: First-line antiplatelet for non-cardioembolic ischemic stroke; lifelong secondary prevention

dosing.instructions: 81 mg PO daily (preferred); 325 mg for first 3 weeks with minor stroke/TIA per CHANCE/POINT then reduce to 81 mg; lifelong

Secondary Prevention (Antiplatelet/Antic.contraindications: Active GI bleeding; aspirin allergy; thrombocytopenia <50K
Secondary Prevention (Antiplatelet/Antic.monitoring: GI symptoms; bleeding signs; annual CBC

Secondary Prevention (Antiplatelet/Antic.indication: Alternative to aspirin if aspirin-intolerant; DAPT with aspirin for 21 days after minor stroke/TIA (CHANCE/POINT protocol)

dosing.instructions: 75 mg PO daily; 300 mg loading dose for acute minor stroke; DAPT: aspirin 81 mg + clopidogrel 75 mg x 21 days then clopidogrel monotherapy

Secondary Prevention (Antiplatelet/Antic.contraindications: Active bleeding; CYP2C19 poor metabolizer (reduced efficacy — consider ticagrelor); thrombocytopenia
Secondary Prevention (Antiplatelet/Antic.monitoring: Bleeding signs; CYP2C19 genotyping if available; platelet function testing rarely needed

Secondary Prevention (Antiplatelet/Antic.indication: Dual antiplatelet x 21 days for minor ischemic stroke (NIHSS ≤3) or high-risk TIA (ABCD2 ≥4) per CHANCE/POINT trials

dosing.instructions: Aspirin 81 mg + clopidogrel 75 mg (with 300 mg clopidogrel load) x 21 days from onset; then monotherapy (aspirin or clopidogrel); DO NOT continue DAPT beyond 21-90 days (increases bleeding without benefit)

Secondary Prevention (Antiplatelet/Antic.monitoring: Bleeding signs closely x 21 days; GI prophylaxis with PPI if high GI risk

Secondary Prevention (Antiplatelet/Antic.indication: Alternative DAPT for minor stroke/TIA per THALES trial; does NOT require CYP2C19 metabolism

dosing.instructions: Ticagrelor 180 mg load then 90 mg BID + aspirin 81 mg x 30 days; then switch to monotherapy; alternative when clopidogrel resistance suspected

Secondary Prevention (Antiplatelet/Antic.contraindications: Active bleeding; history of ICH; severe hepatic impairment; concurrent strong CYP3A4 inhibitors
Secondary Prevention (Antiplatelet/Antic.monitoring: Bleeding; dyspnea (common, usually benign); bradycardia; liver function

Secondary Prevention (Antiplatelet/Antic.indication: Anticoagulation for stroke with AF; preferred DOAC for most patients; superior to warfarin (ARISTOTLE trial)

dosing.instructions: 5 mg BID standard; reduce to 2.5 mg BID if ≥2 of: age ≥80, weight ≤60 kg, creatinine ≥1.5; start 2-14 days after stroke depending on infarct size (1-3-6-12 day rule)

Secondary Prevention (Antiplatelet/Antic.contraindications: Active major bleeding; severe hepatic impairment; mechanical heart valve; pregnancy
Secondary Prevention (Antiplatelet/Antic.monitoring: Renal function q6 months; CBC annually; bleeding signs; Xa level if needed (not routine)

Secondary Prevention (Antiplatelet/Antic.indication: Anticoagulation for stroke with AF; once-daily dosing advantage; ROCKET-AF data

dosing.instructions: 20 mg PO daily with dinner (food enhances absorption); reduce to 15 mg daily if CrCl 15-50 mL/min; timing per infarct size

Secondary Prevention (Antiplatelet/Antic.contraindications: Active major bleeding; CrCl <15; severe hepatic impairment (Child-Pugh C); mechanical valve
Secondary Prevention (Antiplatelet/Antic.monitoring: Renal function q6 months; CBC annually; bleeding signs

Secondary Prevention (Antiplatelet/Antic.indication: Anticoagulation for stroke with AF; RE-LY trial; reversible with idarucizumab

dosing.instructions: 150 mg BID standard; 110 mg BID if age ≥80 or concurrent P-gp inhibitor; CrCl 30-50: 150 mg BID acceptable; avoid if CrCl <30

Secondary Prevention (Antiplatelet/Antic.monitoring: Renal function q6 months (renal elimination); thrombin time or ecarin clotting time if needed; idarucizumab for reversal

Secondary Prevention (Antiplatelet/Antic.indication: Anticoagulation for mechanical heart valve; alternative when DOACs contraindicated; AF in severe renal failure

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg daily (2.5 mg if elderly, low weight, liver disease); adjust to INR 2-3 (2.5-3.5 for mechanical valve); check INR 2-3 days after start, then weekly until stable, then monthly

Secondary Prevention (Antiplatelet/Antic.contraindications: Active major bleeding; pregnancy (teratogenic); severe hepatic failure; non-adherence (requires monitoring)

Symptomatic Treatments (Post-Stroke Comp.indication: Post-stroke depression (affects 30-50% of stroke survivors); FLAME trial showed improved motor recovery; first-line SSRI

dosing.instructions: Start 25 mg daily; increase by 25-50 mg q1-2wk; target 50-200 mg daily; FLAME trial used 20 mg fluoxetine — either SSRI effective

Symptomatic Treatments (Post-Stroke Comp.contraindications: Concurrent MAOIs; caution with anticoagulants (increased bleeding risk with SSRIs)
Symptomatic Treatments (Post-Stroke Comp.monitoring: Suicidality first 4 weeks; bleeding risk with anticoagulants; serotonin syndrome; hyponatremia (especially elderly)

Symptomatic Treatments (Post-Stroke Comp.indication: Post-stroke depression; well tolerated; alternative SSRI

dosing.instructions: Start 5-10 mg daily; max 20 mg; well tolerated in elderly stroke patients

Symptomatic Treatments (Post-Stroke Comp.contraindications: Concurrent MAOIs; QT prolongation; max 10 mg in elderly per FDA
Symptomatic Treatments (Post-Stroke Comp.monitoring: QTc if elderly or QT risk; suicidality; hyponatremia

Symptomatic Treatments (Post-Stroke Comp.indication: Post-stroke spasticity; GABA-B agonist; first-line for focal or generalized spasticity

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg TID; increase by 5 mg/dose q3 days; target 10-20 mg TID; max 80 mg/day; taper slowly (withdrawal seizures)

Symptomatic Treatments (Post-Stroke Comp.monitoring: Sedation; weakness (balance with spasticity reduction); renal function

Symptomatic Treatments (Post-Stroke Comp.indication: Post-stroke spasticity; alpha-2 agonist; alternative or adjunct to baclofen; less weakness but more sedation

dosing.instructions: Start 2 mg qHS; increase by 2 mg q3-7 days; target 4-8 mg TID; max 36 mg/day; sedating — use at bedtime initially

Symptomatic Treatments (Post-Stroke Comp.monitoring: Sedation; weight gain; dizziness; peripheral edema; renal function

Symptomatic Treatments (Post-Stroke Comp.contraindications: Severe hepatic impairment; history of angioedema with modafinil; concurrent hormonal contraceptives (reduces efficacy)
Symptomatic Treatments (Post-Stroke Comp.monitoring: Blood pressure; psychiatric symptoms; insomnia; headache; reduces efficacy of hormonal contraceptives

dosing.instructions: Start 500 mg BID; increase by 500 mg q1-2wk; target 500-1000 mg BID; max 3000 mg/day; no hepatic interactions with stroke medications

Vascular Risk Factor Management.indication: High-intensity statin for all ischemic stroke patients; SPARCL trial demonstrated 16% stroke risk reduction with LDL <70; TST trial supports LDL <70

dosing.instructions: Start 40-80 mg daily; target LDL <70 mg/dL; 80 mg preferred for secondary prevention; take any time of day

Vascular Risk Factor Management.contraindications: Active liver disease; pregnancy; concurrent strong CYP3A4 inhibitors at high doses
Vascular Risk Factor Management.monitoring: LFTs at baseline and 3 months; CK if myalgia; lipid panel q3-6 months until at goal then annually

Vascular Risk Factor Management.indication: High-intensity statin alternative to atorvastatin; may be more potent for LDL lowering; non-CYP3A4 metabolism

dosing.instructions: Start 20 mg daily; may increase to 40 mg; max 40 mg; preferred if CYP3A4 drug interactions a concern

Vascular Risk Factor Management.contraindications: Active liver disease; pregnancy; severe renal impairment (max 10 mg if CrCl <30)
Vascular Risk Factor Management.monitoring: Same as atorvastatin; Asian patients: start 5-10 mg (increased rosuvastatin levels)

Vascular Risk Factor Management.indication: Add-on to statin if LDL not at goal on maximum statin; IMPROVE-IT trial showed benefit

dosing.instructions: 10 mg PO daily; can add to any statin; no dose adjustment needed

Vascular Risk Factor Management.contraindications: Severe hepatic impairment (when combined with statin); hypersensitivity
Vascular Risk Factor Management.monitoring: Lipid panel q3 months after starting until at goal; LFTs with statin combination

PCSK9 inhibitor (evolocumab or alirocumab) alirocumab 75 mg q2wk SC

Vascular Risk Factor Management.indication: First-line ACE inhibitor for post-stroke BP management; target BP <130/80 (SPRINT-like targets for secondary prevention)

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg daily; increase by 5-10 mg q1-2wk; target BP <130/80; max 40 mg

Vascular Risk Factor Management.monitoring: BMP within 2 weeks of starting (creatinine, potassium); BP; cough (switch to ARB if intolerable)

dosing.instructions: Start 25-50 mg daily; increase by 25-50 mg q2-4wk; target BP <130/80; max 100 mg

Vascular Risk Factor Management.monitoring: BMP within 2 weeks; BP; less cough than ACEi

Vascular Risk Factor Management.indication: Calcium channel blocker for post-stroke BP management; add-on to ACEi/ARB; good in elderly; evidence from ASCOT

dosing.instructions: Start 2.5-5 mg daily; increase by 2.5-5 mg q1-2wk; max 10 mg; well tolerated in elderly

Vascular Risk Factor Management.indication: Thiazide-like diuretic for post-stroke BP management; more potent and longer-acting than HCTZ; evidence from ALLHAT

dosing.instructions: Start 12.5 mg daily; increase to 25 mg if needed; max 25 mg; take in morning

Vascular Risk Factor Management.monitoring: BMP (sodium, potassium, creatinine) at 2 weeks and q3-6 months; uric acid; glucose

Vascular Risk Factor Management.indication: First-line for type 2 diabetes in post-stroke patients; cardiovascular benefit; weight neutral

dosing.instructions: Start 500 mg daily with meals; increase by 500 mg q1-2wk; target 1000 mg BID; max 2550 mg/day; extended-release for GI tolerability

Vascular Risk Factor Management.contraindications: eGFR <30; metabolic acidosis; heavy alcohol use; contrast dye (hold 48h)
Vascular Risk Factor Management.monitoring: BMP q3-6 months; HbA1c q3 months until <7% then q6 months; B12 annually (depletion)

Vascular Risk Factor Management.indication: SGLT2 inhibitor for diabetes with cardiovascular benefit; reduces MACE and heart failure; renoprotective

dosing.instructions: Start 10 mg daily; may increase to 25 mg; take in morning; cardiovascular and renal benefit independent of HbA1c

Vascular Risk Factor Management.contraindications: eGFR <20 (for glucose lowering); recurrent UTI/genital infections; type 1 DM
Vascular Risk Factor Management.monitoring: BMP; eGFR; genital infections; volume status; ketoacidosis risk (rare)

Referrals & Consults.item: Physical therapy for gait training, balance, strength, and fall prevention — begin inpatient and continue outpatient; most recovery occurs in first 3-6 months but improvement continues
Occupational therapy for ADL retraining, upper extremity function, adaptive equipment, and energy conservation
Speech-language pathology for aphasia, dysarthria, cognitive-communication deficits, and swallow evaluation (dysphagia screening before oral intake)
Neuropsychological testing at 3-6 months post-stroke for cognitive assessment; vascular cognitive impairment screening; guide rehabilitation goals
Cardiology referral for AF management, PFO closure evaluation (if age <60 + cryptogenic stroke + PFO), heart failure management, or complex antithrombotic decisions
Rehabilitation medicine (physiatry) for comprehensive rehabilitation program coordination; inpatient rehab evaluation if moderate-severe deficits
Psychiatry or psychology referral for post-stroke depression not responding to SSRI within 6-8 weeks; anxiety; PTSD; adjustment disorder
Social work for discharge planning, community resources, disability documentation, caregiver support, and financial assistance
Neurology follow-up in 1-2 weeks post-discharge for medication reconciliation, imaging review, and secondary prevention optimization; then q3-6 months
Driving evaluation by occupational therapist and neurology clearance when appropriate; varies by deficit and state law
Vascular surgery or neurointerventional referral if symptomatic carotid stenosis ≥50% for CEA/CAS evaluation

Patient Instructions.item: Learn and recognize stroke warning signs (FAST: Face drooping, Arm weakness, Speech difficulty, Time to call 911); call 911 immediately if any symptom recurs — do not drive yourself

Take all medications as prescribed; DO NOT stop antiplatelet, anticoagulant, or statin medications without consulting your neurologist — stopping these medications significantly increases recurrent stroke risk
Monitor blood pressure at home twice daily (morning and evening) using validated automatic cuff; keep a log and bring to all appointments; target <130/80
Do not drive until cleared by your neurologist; stroke can affect vision, reaction time, and judgment; formal driving evaluation may be required
Participate actively in all prescribed rehabilitation therapies (PT, OT, speech); most recovery occurs in first 3-6 months but improvement can continue for years
Report new mood changes, persistent sadness, loss of interest, or involuntary crying/laughing to your neurologist — post-stroke depression and pseudobulbar affect are common and treatable
Maintain a medication list including all prescriptions, doses, and schedule; bring to every medical visit and keep a copy in your wallet
If on anticoagulation (apixaban, rivaroxaban, warfarin): report any unusual bleeding (gums, nosebleed, blood in urine/stool, easy bruising); carry anticoagulant alert card

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Smoking cessation is the single most important lifestyle modification; reduces recurrent stroke risk by 50%; offer nicotine replacement, varenicline, or bupropion; referral to cessation program
Mediterranean-style or DASH diet: rich in fruits, vegetables, whole grains, fish, olive oil; limit sodium to <2300 mg/day (1500 mg if hypertensive); limit processed foods and red meat
Regular aerobic exercise: 30 minutes of moderate-intensity exercise (walking, swimming, cycling) 5 days/week; adapted to functional level; reduces stroke recurrence by 20-25%
Limit alcohol to ≤1 drink/day for women, ≤2 drinks/day for men; heavy alcohol increases hemorrhagic stroke risk; complete abstinence preferred if AF or liver disease
Weight management: target BMI 18.5-25; waist circumference <40" (men) / <35" (women); even modest weight loss (5-10%) improves vascular risk factors
Diabetes management: target HbA1c <7% (individualize for elderly); regular glucose monitoring; medication adherence; annual diabetic screening (eyes, feet, kidneys)
Sleep apnea screening (present in 50-70% of stroke patients); STOP-BANG questionnaire; polysomnography if positive; CPAP improves vascular outcomes

differential.features: New focal deficit; DWI-positive on MRI; may be same or different vascular territory; reassess etiology
differential.tests: MRI/DWI (new acute infarct); vascular imaging; cardiac evaluation

differential.features: Headache; worsening deficit; on anticoagulation/antiplatelet; typically occurs days 3-7 post-stroke
differential.tests: CT head (hemorrhage within infarct territory); manage anticoagulation

differential.features: New seizure (focal or generalized); may mimic stroke (Todd paralysis); typically occurs within first year
differential.tests: EEG; MRI (no new infarct on DWI); seizure semiology

differential.features: Reduced motivation; flat affect; cognitive slowing; may mimic cognitive decline from vascular dementia
Progressive cognitive decline; executive dysfunction; gait disturbance; strategic infarct dementia
differential.tests: Neuropsychological testing; MRI (strategic infarcts, white matter disease); exclude Alzheimer overlap

differential.features: Contralateral burning/stinging pain; allodynia; typically thalamic stroke; onset weeks-months post-stroke
differential.tests: Clinical diagnosis; MRI (thalamic infarct); exclude other pain causes

differential.features: Weakness and fatigue from prolonged bed rest; orthostatic symptoms; not focal
differential.tests: Orthostatic vitals; functional assessment; PT evaluation

differential.features: Cognitive slowing; fatigue; sedation from post-stroke medications; overlap with stroke sequelae
differential.tests: Medication review; trial dose reduction; timing of symptoms

evidence.recommendation: DAPT (aspirin + clopidogrel) x 21 days for minor stroke/high-risk TIA reduces recurrent stroke
evidence.source: [Wang et al. NEJM 2013 (CHANCE)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/23803136/); [Johnston et al. NEJM 2018 (POINT)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/29766750/)

evidence.recommendation: High-intensity statin with LDL <70 for secondary stroke prevention
evidence.source: [Amarenco et al. NEJM 2006 (SPARCL)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/16899775/); [Amarenco et al. NEJM 2020 (TST)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/33053300/)

evidence.recommendation: Apixaban superior to warfarin for stroke prevention in AF
BP target <130/80 for secondary stroke prevention
PFO closure for cryptogenic stroke age <60 with moderate-large shunt
evidence.source: [Mas et al. NEJM 2017 (CLOSE)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/28902580/); [Søndergaard et al. NEJM 2017 (REDUCE)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/28902580/)

evidence.recommendation: SSRIs improve post-stroke depression and may improve motor recovery
Early mobilization and rehabilitation improve outcomes post-stroke
Implantable loop recorder detects 30% AF at 3 years in cryptogenic stroke
Sleep apnea highly prevalent post-stroke; CPAP may improve outcomes
Mediterranean diet reduces recurrent cardiovascular events
